summary: This is a November 16, 2007 editorial from The Palm Beach Post criticizing the potential plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein. It argues that a plea to a single felony count of solicitation of prostitution, which does not acknowledge the underage status of the victims, would be an injustice. The editorial highlights the involvement of high-profile attorneys and questions whether wealth is influencing the criminal justice process.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: A part-time Palm Beach resident and Manhattan money manager indicted by a grand jury in July 2006 on one felony count of solicitation of prostitution for paying underage girls for 'massage' sessions.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: The State Attorney who, after being informed by Epstein's attorneys about the alleged victims' MySpace pages, sent the case to a grand jury instead of filing charges himself.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: A West Palm Beach defense attorney on Jeffrey Epstein's legal team who stated the case would end without a trial within two months.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: A Harvard Law School professor and member of Epstein's legal team, noted for his work on the O.J. Simpson murder case.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: A member of Jeffrey Epstein's legal team, formerly known for pursuing President Bill Clinton.

persons.name: Jose Lambiet
persons.context: A reporter for The Palm Beach Post who wrote an article citing an unnamed source close to Epstein about the status of the federal investigation.

persons.name: Michael Edmondson
persons.context: Spokesman for the State Attorney who would not confirm a plea deal but noted the state attorney could file additional charges beyond the grand jury indictment.

connections.description: Goldberger is a defense attorney on Epstein's legal team and spoke to the press about the expected resolution of the case.
Dershowitz is a Harvard Law professor and member of Epstein's defense team.
Starr is a member of Epstein's high-profile legal defense team.
Krischer, as State Attorney, was the prosecutor who decided to send the police case against Epstein to a grand jury.
Goldberger provided information about the case's expected resolution to reporter Jose Lambiet.

events.title: Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: A Palm Beach County grand jury indicted Jeffrey Epstein on one felony count of solicitation of prostitution.

events.title: Report on Federal Investigation Conclusion
events.description: Reporter Jose Lambiet, citing an unnamed source close to Epstein, wrote that the federal investigation was over and Epstein was expected to serve up to 18 months and be labeled a sex offender.

events.title: Editorial on Plea Deal
events.description: The Palm Beach Post published an editorial criticizing the potential plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein, arguing it would be an injustice that fails to acknowledge the underage victims.

keyFacts: A Palm Beach County grand jury indicted Jeffrey Epstein in July 2006 on one felony count of solicitation of prostitution.
Police alleged Epstein paid underage girls, one as young as 14, for 'massage' sessions at his Palm Beach home.
State Attorney Barry Krischer sent the case to a grand jury after Epstein's attorneys presented information about the alleged victims' MySpace pages.
Epstein's high-profile legal team included Jack Goldberger, Alan Dershowitz, and Kenneth Starr.
As of November 2007, a plea deal was anticipated where Epstein might serve up to 18 months and be labeled a sex offender, a lesser penalty than the grand jury charge's maximum five-year term.
